@michaelbd indeed
@michaelbd court might make up something new, but surprised by the mythological accounts of status quo bandied about by both libs & cons
@michaelbd bc there's no precedent that signing a form is a substantial burden; there is precedent that signing a form is compelled speech
@yeselson @michaelbd @jeffspross @eliasisquith  and no one is; subst. burden is a separate inquiry
@michaelbd @yeselson @jeffspross @eliasisquith the crucial Q the Court will answer is whether penalties for noncompliance suffice to show SB
@michaelbd @yeselson @jeffspross @eliasisquith i'm exceedingly familiar with the args (1/2)
@michaelbd @yeselson @jeffspross @eliasisquith i know that, but that is the basis on which you could attack "I authorize" language
@michaelbd @yeselson @jeffspross @eliasisquith they can characterize however they like, but have to show a substantial burden
@michaelbd @yeselson @jeffspross @eliasisquith there is no compelled speech arg before the Court
@yeselson @michaelbd @jeffspross @eliasisquith no he didn't; he said the penalties for non-compliance constituted a substantial burden

@michaelbd @yeselson @jeffspross @eliasisquith that would likely
 fail on FA grounds
@yeselson @michaelbd @jeffspross @eliasisquith consider the draft: can it be the law of the land that filing a CO app is a subst. burden?
@yeselson @michaelbd @jeffspross @eliasisquith re-affirm that substantial burden is an objective test, and that filling out a form fails it
@yeselson @michaelbd @jeffspross @eliasisquith *but
@yeselson @michaelbd @jeffspross @eliasisquith if cases even get to least restrictive analysis, Court will have broken with all not one CC
@michaelbd @jeffspross that may have been intentionally confusing on Alito's part, and we'll find out
@michaelbd @jeffspross SC said it's not for them to say the belief is "insubstantial"
@michaelbd @jeffspross the Supreme Court did not say that in Hobby Lobby; if they do now, would work a revolution in the law
@michaelbd @jeffspross of course they do; oath laws fall on FA grounds; RFRA substantial burden inq'y however is an objective one
@jeffspross @michaelbd live issue is whether signing a form is ever a substantial burden; implications are enormous, hence DOJ resistance
